Question Text: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for establishing, managing, and terminating connections between devices? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Transport layer
b. Session layer
c. Data link layer
d. Presentation layer
LLM Explanation: The session layer (OSI layer 5) is responsible for establishing, managing (dialog control, synchronization, checkpoints) and terminating sessions (connections) between applications on different devices. The transport layer provides end-to-end data transfer and reliability but not the session management functions attributed to layer 5.

Question Text: Which model defines seven layers of networking protocols? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. OSI model
b. DoD model
c. TCP/IP model
d. Ethernet model
LLM Explanation: The OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) reference model defines seven distinct layers: Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Session, Presentation, and Application. The DoD/TCP‑IP models use fewer layers (commonly four), and Ethernet is a link-layer technology rather than a seven-layer reference model.

Question Text: Which device is used to enforce security policies by controlling the incoming and outgoing network traffic? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Network switch
b. Router
c. Modem
d. Firewall
LLM Explanation: A firewall is the device specifically designed to enforce security policies by inspecting and allowing or blocking incoming and outgoing network traffic (can be packet-filtering, stateful, or application-layer). Routers forward between networks (and may have basic ACLs), switches operate at Layer 2 for LAN connectivity, and modems convert signals for WAN access but do not primarily enforce security policies.

Question Text: Which device is responsible for determining the best path for data packets to travel across multiple networks? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Network switch
b. Router
c. Modem
d. Bridge
LLM Explanation: A router is the device that operates at the network layer (Layer 3) and uses routing tables and routing protocols (e.g., OSPF, BGP) to determine the best path for packets between different networks. Switches and bridges operate at Layer 2 (forwarding within a LAN), and a modem only converts signals between digital and analog domains.

Question Text: Which network topology consists of a single shared communication line to which all devices are connected? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Bus topology
b. Star topology
c. Ring topology
d. Mesh topology
LLM Explanation: Bus topology uses a single shared communication line (backbone) to which all devices are attached (each device taps into the common bus). Other topologies use central hubs (star), closed loop links (ring), or multiple interconnections (mesh).

Question Text: Which network topology requires the least amount of cabling and is easy to set up, but if the central device fails, the entire network becomes inaccessible? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Bus topology
b. Star topology
c. Ring topology
d. Mesh topology
LLM Explanation: Star topology uses a central hub/switch to which all nodes connect (point-to-point links). It is simple to install and manage, and troubleshooting is straightforward, but the central device is a single point of failure — if it fails the whole network becomes inaccessible. (Note: a pure bus uses even less cabling overall, but only the star matches the description of a central-device single point of failure.)

Question Text: Which device can be used to create logical network segments and improve network performance by reducing network congestion? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Network switch
b. Router
c. Modem
d. Repeater
LLM Explanation: A network switch (Layer 2) creates separate collision domains per port and, with VLAN support, can create logical network segments. By forwarding frames only to the destination port or VLAN, a switch reduces unnecessary traffic and network congestion. Routers separate broadcast domains between networks but are not typically used to create logical LAN segments within the same switch fabric; modems and repeaters do not provide segmentation or traffic isolation.

Question Text: The DoD model is commonly known as the:
Choices:
a. Four-layer model
b. Five-layer model
c. Six-layer model
d. Seven-layer model
LLM Explanation: The DoD model refers to the TCP/IP (Internet) protocol suite, commonly depicted as a four-layer model: Application, Transport, Internet, and Link (network access). Thus it is known as the four-layer model.

Question Text: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for addressing and routing packets? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Network layer
b. Data link layer
c. Transport layer
d. Physical layer
LLM Explanation: The Network layer (Layer 3) is responsible for logical addressing (e.g., IP addresses) and routing packets between different networks. The Data Link layer (Layer 2) handles MAC addressing and frame delivery on a single link, the Transport layer (Layer 4) provides end-to-end communication services, and the Physical layer (Layer 1) transmits raw bits over the medium.

Question Text: Which layer of the OSI model provides encryption and decryption of data for secure communication? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Presentation layer
b. Session layer
c. Application layer
d. Physical layer
LLM Explanation: The Presentation layer (OSI Layer 6) is responsible for data representation functions such as translation, compression, and encryption/decryption to ensure that data sent by the application layer of one system can be read by the application layer of another.

Question Text: Which device can be used to connect two or more network segments together and extend the reach of a network? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Network switch
b. Router
c. Modem
d. Bridge
LLM Explanation: A bridge is the device specifically designed to join two or more LAN segments into a single logical network and thus extend the reach of the network. Bridges operate at the Data Link layer (Layer 2), forwarding frames based on MAC addresses. (A switch is essentially a multi‑port bridge, a router connects separate IP networks at Layer 3, and a modem performs modulation/demodulation for WAN access.)

Question Text: Which device can perform Network Address Translation (NAT) to allow multiple devices on a private network to share a single public IP address? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Network switch
b. Router
c. Modem
d. Bridge
LLM Explanation: Routers (especially residential/home routers and gateway devices) perform Network Address Translation (NAT) — typically PAT/port translation — allowing multiple private IP addresses to share a single public IP. Switches and bridges operate at Layer 2 and don’t perform NAT; modems translate physical/line signals but don’t provide IP-level NAT by themselves.

Question Text: Which network topology provides redundant connections between devices, ensuring multiple paths for data transmission? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Bus topology
b. Star topology
c. Ring topology
d. Mesh topology
LLM Explanation: Mesh topology provides redundant connections between devices so there are multiple alternative paths for data transmission (full mesh: every node connected to every other; partial mesh: some multiple paths). This redundancy increases fault tolerance and reliability compared with bus, star, or ring topologies.

Question Text: Which network topology uses a central device that connects all devices in a star-like fashion? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Bus topology
b. Star topology
c. Ring topology
d. Mesh topology
LLM Explanation: Star topology connects all devices to a single central device (hub, switch, or router) which acts as the common connection point; communication between end nodes passes through that central device.

Question Text: Which device is primarily used to connect multiple devices within a local area network (LAN)? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Network switch
b. Router
c. Modem
d. Hub
LLM Explanation: A network switch is the primary device used to connect multiple devices within a LAN. Switches operate at Layer 2 (data link) and forward frames based on MAC addresses, providing dedicated bandwidth per port and reducing collisions compared with hubs. Routers connect separate networks (or a LAN to the internet), modems convert between digital and analog signals for ISP access, and hubs are legacy, less intelligent devices that simply broadcast signals to all ports.

Question Text: Which layer of the OSI model provides encryption and decryption of data for secure communication? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Presentation layer
b. Session layer
c. Application layer
d. Physical layer
LLM Explanation: The Presentation layer (OSI Layer 6) is responsible for data translation, formatting, compression, and encryption/decryption to provide a common representation for the application layer. (In practical implementations, protocols like TLS/SSL are often placed at the boundary between application and transport, but in the conceptual OSI model encryption/decryption is attributed to the Presentation layer.)

Question Text: Which device operates at Layer 2 of the OSI model and uses MAC addresses to forward network traffic? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Network switch
b. Router
c. Modem
d. Firewall
LLM Explanation: A network switch operates at the OSI Data Link layer (Layer 2) and forwards Ethernet frames based on MAC addresses stored in its MAC address table. Routers operate at Layer 3 (use IP addresses); a modem converts signals between networks and a firewall enforces policies (often at Layers 3/4 or above).

Question Text: Which device provides wireless network connectivity within a local area network (LAN)? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Network switch
b. Router
c. Modem
d. Wireless access point
LLM Explanation: A wireless access point (WAP) provides Wi‑Fi connectivity for devices within a LAN, allowing wireless clients to connect to the local network and (usually via a switch/router) to other networks. Switches provide wired ports, routers forward between networks (and may include a WAP), and modems connect the LAN to the ISP but do not themselves provide Wi‑Fi access.

Question Text: Which network protocol is used for remote login and command execution on network devices? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. DHCP
b. DNS
c. FTP
d. Telnet
LLM Explanation: Telnet is the protocol designed for remote terminal access—allowing users to log into network devices and execute commands remotely. DHCP is for IP address/configuration assignment, DNS resolves domain names to IPs, and FTP is for file transfer, not interactive remote command execution. Note: Telnet is insecure (plaintext); SSH is the secure replacement in most environments.

Question Text: Which network protocol is responsible for error reporting and diagnostics in IP networks? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. ARP
b. DHCP
c. ICMP
d. NAT
LLM Explanation: ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol) is the protocol used in IP networks specifically for error reporting and network diagnostics (e.g., echo request/reply for ping, time exceeded for traceroute). ARP resolves MAC-to-IP addresses, DHCP assigns IP configuration, and NAT translates addresses—none of which are for error reporting/diagnostics.

Question Text: Which network protocol is used for time synchronization in a network? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. ARP
b. DHCP
c. NTP
d. NAT
LLM Explanation: NTP (Network Time Protocol) is the standard protocol used to synchronize clocks of computers and network devices across packet-switched networks. ARP resolves IP-to-MAC addresses, DHCP assigns IP configuration (it can provide NTP server info but does not perform time sync itself), and NAT performs address translation — none of which provide time synchronization.

Question Text: How many host addresses are available in a Class C network? Choose only one.
LLM Explanation: A Class C network uses a default mask of 255.255.255.0 (/24), which provides 2^8 = 256 total IP addresses. Two addresses are reserved (network and broadcast), leaving 256 - 2 = 254 usable host addresses.

Question Text: What is the maximum number of IP addresses that can be assigned in a /26 subnet? Choose only one.
LLM Explanation: A /26 leaves 32 - 26 = 6 host bits, so 2^6 = 64 total IPv4 addresses. Two addresses are reserved (network and broadcast), so 64 - 2 = 62 usable/assignable addresses.

Question Text: What is the purpose of the subnet mask in TCP/IP networking? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. To identify the network address
b. To identify the broadcast address
c. To determine the number of available hosts
d. To define the range of assignable IP addresses
LLM Explanation: A subnet mask specifies which bits of an IP address are the network (versus host) portion. Applying the mask (bitwise AND) to an IP yields the network address. While you can derive broadcast address or host count from the mask, its primary purpose is to identify the network portion and thus the network address.

Question Text: How many bits are used to represent an IPv6 address? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. 32 bits
b. 64 bits
c. 128 bits
d. 256 bits
LLM Explanation: IPv6 addresses are 128 bits long. They are typically written as eight 16-bit hexadecimal groups separated by colons (8 × 16 = 128 bits).

Question Text: Which transport protocol is commonly used for web browsing, file transfer, and email communication?
Choices:
a. TCP
b. UDP
LLM Explanation: TCP. Web browsing (HTTP/HTTPS), file transfer (FTP) and email protocols (SMTP, POP3, IMAP) use TCP because they require a reliable, ordered, connection-oriented transport service for correct data delivery.

Question Text: Which transport protocol is commonly used for streaming media and real-time communication?
Choices:
a. TCP
b. UDP
LLM Explanation: UDP. User Datagram Protocol is connectionless and has low overhead with no built‑in retransmission, so it minimizes latency and jitter—properties important for real‑time applications (VoIP, video conferencing, live streaming). RTP (the common real‑time media protocol) typically runs over UDP. TCP’s reliability mechanisms and retransmissions introduce delays that make it less suitable for real‑time streaming.

Question Text: Which transport protocol guarantees the order of packet delivery?
Choices:
a. TCP
b. UDP
LLM Explanation: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) provides reliable, connection-oriented, ordered byte-stream delivery using sequence numbers, acknowledgements, retransmission, and reassembly. UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is connectionless and does not guarantee ordering or reliability.

Question Text: Which transport protocol provides flow control and congestion control mechanisms?
Choices:
a. TCP
b. UDP
LLM Explanation: TCP implements both flow control (receiver-advertised window / sliding-window mechanisms) and congestion control (algorithms such as slow start, congestion avoidance, fast retransmit and fast recovery). UDP is connectionless and does not provide built-in flow or congestion control.
URLs: ['https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc793', 'https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5681', 'https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc768', 'Kurose, J. F. & Ross, K. W., Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (textbook)']

Question Text: Which transport protocol provides unreliable, connectionless communication?
Choices:
a. TCP
b. UDP
LLM Explanation: UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is a connectionless transport protocol that provides unreliable, best-effort datagram delivery (no handshake, no guaranteed delivery, ordering, or retransmission). TCP is connection-oriented and provides reliable, ordered delivery.
URLs: ['https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc768', 'https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc793', 'http://gaia.cs.umass.edu/kurose_ross/online_lectures/ (Kurose & Ross, Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach)']

Question Text: Which IP address class range is reserved for private networks? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Class A
b. Class B
c. Class C
d. Class D
LLM Explanation: IPv4 private address ranges per RFC 1918 are: Class A: 10.0.0.0/8 (10.0.0.0–10.255.255.255); Class B: 172.16.0.0/12 (172.16.0.0–172.31.255.255); Class C: 192.168.0.0/16 (192.168.0.0–192.168.255.255). Class D addresses (224.0.0.0–239.255.255.255) are reserved for multicast, not private host addressing.

Question Text: Which network protocol is used for secure web browsing over an encrypted connection? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. DHCP
b. DNS
c. HTTPS
d. SMTP
LLM Explanation: HTTPS (HTTP over TLS/SSL) provides HTTP communication over an encrypted TLS/SSL connection for secure web browsing. DHCP is for IP address/configuration, DNS resolves domain names, and SMTP is for email transfer—not for secure web browsing.

Question Text: Which network protocol is used for time synchronization in a network? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. ARP
b. DHCP
c. NTP
d. NAT
LLM Explanation: NTP (Network Time Protocol) is the protocol specifically designed to synchronize clocks across networked devices. ARP resolves IP to MAC addresses, DHCP assigns IP configuration parameters (it can provide NTP server info but does not perform time synchronization), and NAT translates IP addresses.

Question Text: Which wireless security protocol is vulnerable to brute-force attacks? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. WEP
b. WPA
c. WPA2
d. WPA3
LLM Explanation: WEP is fundamentally insecure (weak RC4 use and a 24-bit IV leading to key reuse and very short effective keyspace), making it trivially breakable by brute‑force/key‑recovery attacks. WPA/WPA2 (especially in enterprise modes) are much stronger; WPA/WPA2‑PSK can be subject to offline dictionary attacks if a weak passphrase is used, while WPA3 (SAE) was designed to resist offline brute‑force attacks.

Question Text: Which wireless encryption method is considered the most secure? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. WEP
b. TKIP
c. AES
d. SSL
LLM Explanation: AES is the strongest choice for wireless encryption. Modern Wi‑Fi standards (WPA2/WPA3) use AES-based ciphers (AES‑CCM or AES‑GCM) for link-layer confidentiality and integrity. WEP is known to be cryptographically broken (RC4/IV weaknesses), TKIP was a short-term fix for WEP and is deprecated, and SSL is a transport-layer protocol (not a Wi‑Fi link-layer encryption method).

Question Text: Which wireless technology allows devices to connect without the need for a central access point? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Ad-hoc mode
b. Infrastructure mode
c. Mesh networking
d. Wi-Fi Direct
LLM Explanation: Ad-hoc mode (also called an IBSS) is a peer-to-peer wireless mode where stations communicate directly with each other without any central access point. Infrastructure mode requires an AP, mesh networking uses routed/relayed nodes to form a network (often with gateways), and Wi‑Fi Direct is a newer peer-to-peer standard but the classic, textbook answer for connecting devices without an AP is ad-hoc mode.

Question Text: Which wireless technology allows multiple access points to work together as a single network? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Ad-hoc mode
b. Infrastructure mode
c. Mesh networking
d. Wi-Fi Direct
LLM Explanation: Mesh networking. In a wireless mesh, multiple access points (mesh nodes) cooperate to form a single logical network (often a single SSID) and route traffic among themselves, enabling seamless roaming, redundancy and extended coverage. Ad-hoc and Wi‑Fi Direct are peer‑to‑peer device modes, and infrastructure mode is a single AP/client model, not multiple APs collaborating as one mesh.

Question Text: Which wireless technology allows wireless devices to connect to a wired network? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Ad-hoc mode
b. Infrastructure mode
c. Mesh networking
d. Wi-Fi Direct
LLM Explanation: Infrastructure mode uses wireless access points (APs) that bridge wireless clients to the wired network (LAN). Ad-hoc and Wi‑Fi Direct are peer-to-peer device-to-device modes (no AP to the wired LAN), and mesh networking is a multi-hop wireless topology (only gateways connect the mesh to a wired network). Thus infrastructure mode is the option that directly allows wireless devices to connect to a wired network.

Question Text: Which wireless technology is commonly used for short-range communication between devices? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Bluetooth
b. NFC
c. Zigbee
d. Z-Wave
LLM Explanation: Bluetooth is the most commonly used short-range wireless technology for direct device-to-device communication (e.g., phones to headsets, keyboards, mice, speakers). NFC is extremely short-range (near-field) and mainly used for payments/pairing; Zigbee and Z-Wave are low-power mesh protocols used mainly for home automation rather than general-purpose device-to-device connectivity.

Question Text: Which wireless technology is commonly used for contactless payment systems? Choose only one.
Choices:
a. Bluetooth
b. NFC
c. Zigbee
d. Z-Wave
LLM Explanation: NFC (Near Field Communication) is the short-range radio technology specifically designed for secure, contactless transactions and is widely used by payment systems (e.g., Apple Pay, Google Pay, contactless cards). Bluetooth is longer-range and not the standard for contactless payments; Zigbee and Z-Wave are primarily IoT/home-automation protocols, not payment technologies.

Question Text: Which wireless standard operates in the 5 GHz frequency band? Choose only one.
LLM Explanation: IEEE 802.11ac (Wi‑Fi 5) is a 5 GHz standard designed for operation in the 5 GHz band. 802.11b and 802.11g operate in 2.4 GHz, and 802.11n is dual‑band (2.4 GHz and 5 GHz), so the single-best choice that specifically operates in 5 GHz is 802.11ac.

Question Text: Which wireless standard provides the highest data transfer rates? Choose only one.
LLM Explanation: 802.11ac provides the highest data rates of the listed standards. It operates in the 5 GHz band with much wider channel widths (up to 80/160 MHz), higher-order modulation (256‑QAM), and multiple spatial streams (MIMO), enabling multi‑hundred‑Mbps to multi‑Gbps throughput. 802.11a and 802.11g top out at about 54 Mbps, and 802.11b at 11 Mbps.
